reviewText:
I'm a fan of the original JA games. This one started out ok, but turned into a disappointment way too quick.

What I simply don't like in this one is the difficulty curve, or should I say the steep changes in enemy arsenal and numbers. First you're up against like six enemies equipped with machetes and revolvers. Next sector you're up against 20 guys with assault rifles and grenades. I mean... WHAT?! In the old JA games, there were never such differences between neighboring areas, save for late-game ones.

Then there's the issue with very micromanage-y combat, hard to read environments (sometimes a branch of a tree blocks vision, other times a man-sized ventilation shaft offers zero protection) and clunky interface that by default assumes you want to keep queueing new actions to happen after old ones are complete, unless you manually clear old orders first. Every. Single. Time. Guns also can't be fired in melee range, apparently, and melee hits register still after the target is ten meters away.

Lots of potential, but poor execution and lack of steady progression killed the fun for me way too quick. Can't recommend. Shame.

After logging many hours on this game in the last two years, I finally decided to write a review. My taste in PC games mostly includes the strategy (especially turn based and pausable RTS) genre. I'm a fan of the X-Com Games, The Total War Series, Close Combat, etc. I played all of the Jagged Alliance Games and enjoyed them all. In my opinion, JABIA is a good game if you like this type of game; a game that requires a lot of management (inventory, strategy, assembling teams, et.). I found the planning and execution of my plans in this game a lot of fun. There are a few rough edges. They could have included a way to look at items ordered after you ordered them, as in the old JA Games. As it is now, you place the order and you have to remember what you ordered until it arrives and the only place it can arrive is at the Drassen Airport, requiring a lot of 'mule' trips by your mercs who will spend much of their time running back and forth for supplies and using newly hired mercs as mules when they come in. The end result of this is that I found myself spending much of my time organizing logistics for reenforcement and resupply. If, like me, you enjoy this in a game, then you won't mind it and may even have fun with it. If this kind of micro-management isn't to your taste, skip this game.

The other part of the game is the tactical combat. This is done using a real time pausable system that requires many pauses and movement order updates during combat to be succesful (survive). With a small group of mercs (one or two teams of 6 each) it can be very exciting and great fun, but as the game goes on, and especially when you are getting ready for the final assaults on the enemy strongholds, you will probably have several dozen mercs going against hundreds of bad guys in just a few sectors. At this point the tactical combat becomes overwhelming as it is virtually impossible to be everywhere at once and are therefore forced to send a small group of mercs at a time against many enemies to whittle them down slowly, and it becomes a drawn out meat grinder of attrition. Not much sneaking around, tactical planning here. Just a whole bunch of shooting against very long odds. I think JA2 did much better by forcing the player, VIA limited finances and merc contracts, to run fewer teams and keep the game managable, while not requiring quite so many mercs to succesfully complete the game.  When you hire mercs in BIA, you pay the fee up front and they are yours for the whole campaign regardless of the length of time they work for you, and the money you find and earn in this game will easily run into the hundreds of thousands, so there is a balance issue here. Also, militia are pretty innafective, and when they die the weapons you equip them with dissapear. I found it much more effective, once you've been in the game for awhile to just leave teams of mercs within striking distance of primary towns and mines that you have captured and send them in when enemies try to attack. Mercs can move amazingly fast along roads and, as mentioned before, you'll have the money and therefore can afford the extra mercs to do the job.

Some things I really like about this game:

-Friendly fire is a threat. This adds some realism that I welcome, especially with grenades and explosives. You don't have the automatic grenade placement of the new Xcom. Watch out for that tree branch...Hit the dirt!"

-The strategic logistical and organizational planning and the tactical planning for each sector. A lot of fun here if you like that sort of thing.

I've tried time and time again to like this game. I install it, play it for a while, and every time I have to uninstall it because I'm so immensely frustrated at the shoddy mechanics. The camera is fine for everything but actually seeing what you're doing, and you need to point and click where you want characters to go based on the camera's view. Point and click, mind you, on any pixel in a large map with thousands of tiny variations in elevation which can mean the difference between spotting and shooting and enemy or being blinded by the tip of a mintue hill. You CONSTANTLY have to deal with adjusting your position so you're behind cover but still able to see and shoot the AI, who by the way, do not have to deal with ANY of what I've complained about so far.

There are so many other small things I could complain about, but the above is what's making me vow to never play this again. Who would have thought a grid system would be make or break for this kind of game.

On the plus side, I really like the idea of a plan and go tactics game.

This review is for the Windows version. The MAC/Linux version is unplayable at this point.

I am a fan of JA2 and i was quite disappointed when JABIA was released. It was unfinished and overpriced on release. But things have changed. Most of the game's problems can be fixed by using mods and the price of the game has decreased considerably. I played the modded Windows version for 220 hours and really enjoyed it. I can only recommend this game.

The story/scheme of the game is very similar to JA2: You are hired to liberate a small 3rd world country and can only afford to send in a few wannabe mercenaries. You start to liberate/loot remote locations in order to get your hands on more money and better weapons while you recruit NPCs and improve their skills.

In contrast to JA2 this game is in 3D and in real time. Which is awesome in my opinion. You dont have to watch 40 AI moves until it is your turn. You can pause and intervene at any time. The game offers a lot of freedom. You can run away from tough battles and come back later with better equipment. You can even leave the first battle of the game and explore instead.

There are a few flaws, however:
-Mercs have less character compared to JA2 and there is no option to create your own mercenary.
-AI is just as stupid as in JA2 and attack squads are very predictable
-Animations in this game feel like placeholders (all weapons have same reload animation and sound)
-Annoying melee combat. Guns cannot be fired at melee range and melee hits damage all of your gear.
-Explosives (C4) can only be placed on brittle walls. you cannot set traps for enemies.
-You will spend a lot of time managing your inventory
-Militia is not very useful and recruiting is tedious.
-You cannot train/repair/heal on the strategical map (which was a nice feature in JA2)
-Enemies cheat / have superhuman skill (fixed by mod)
-Weapons are imbalanced and have wierd stats (fixed by mod)
-Broken Stealth: enemies hear you walk/climb from up to 150m (fixed by mod)
-Broken Camouflage: camouflage not working properly, especially at night (fixed by mod)
People also complain about horrible aimtime in CQC, but this can be solved by using the Run stance (F3) at close range. This will result in rapid-fire instead of aimed-fire.

Some reviewers claim that combat gameplay is micromanagy" and "tedious". In my opinion combat is very simple and entertaining as long as you avoid common mistakes and use hotkeys. It is even possible to play the game completely in real time without any pausing as long as you know what you are doing.

reviewText:
In many ways this game is an improvement on Jagged Alliance 2. Besides the obvious graphics updates, the pausable-real-time combat engine works well, and the 3D map layouts provide both challenges and opportunities. Figuring out how to assault a road block or clear out a building is quite rewarding.

What really kills the game is that everything besides the combat is extremely tedious. Managing inventory, amor, militia and your mercs should be a pleasant change of pace between combat, but running around buying a gun and then figuring out which door you need to open so that you can give it to a militiaman is more trouble than it's worth.

The little cutscenes from JA2 - corny as they were - also appear to be missing, so the game feels almost bereft of plot or character.

After a couple of dozen hours, I've liberated just under half of Arulco, but I feel like I've already experienced everything the game has to offer.

reviewText:
This could have been a great game. It had the potential to be a worthy successor to the excellent JA1 and JA2 games of our youth. Nice graphics, a decent combat system. Unfortunately, it seems they never really got round to finishing the game. It's like they cut a load of corners, spent too much time designing junk items (like a wide variety of t-shirts and food items), didn't properly test it, rushed it to market and then started on the DLC cashgrab as soon as they could.

A few gripes and missing features :

There's several really annoying bugs (for example, items in sector inventory will disappear randomly and only reappear if you save and reload). Gameplay is unbalanced - expect to face off against skilled, well-armed enemies with your two or three pistol-wielding mercs pretty early on. If you move into an occupied sector, expect to be dumped right next to the enemy forces - you need to move next to the danger area and manually enter the zone if you want to try any kind of stealthy approach.

There are cars and lorries all over the landscape but none of them are usable. Forget about quick transport between locations.

Explosives can only be used at specific weak points in walls so forget about making your own entrance to a building. You'll often find locks that can't be picked or forced. You can't shoot locks or blow up doors.

Mercs and militia will happily jump on landmines, even when they've been detected. There's no autopause when a mine is detected, either, so if you're sending a merc through a potentially mined area, do so carefully.

The militia system has been horribly simplified. Rather than go through the tedium of vetting recruits and teaching them to use guns, why not just hand that random person on the street, potentially violent prisoner in a locked cell or hospital patient found in a locked ward an assault rifle? What could possibly go wrong?

Only one weapon attachment is allowed at a time and is removed if you change weapons. Want a silencer, laser sight and fancy optics on that gun? Forget it. Want to switch to another gun when your inventory is full? Drop something first.

Shooting an enemy will interrupt and stun them (fine, that's a good idea) yet hitting them with a baseball bat or machete doesn't, allowing the enemy a chance to beat the snot out of your merc.

IMP no longer exists. Forget about making your own merc.

Enjoyed those witty interactions between mercs or those cutscenes of Deidranna abusing her staff in JA2? Interesting, well-written dialogue with NPCs? You won't find them here. By the time you're storming the palace you'll just want the game to be over and done with.

Conclusion : Meh. Don't bother. Unless it's really, really cheap in a sale.

reviewText:
Long-waited revival of Jagged Alliance experience in full 3 dimensions. Jagged Alliance 2, simply put, is the king of the small, but proud sub-genre of strategies, namely, a squad-based tactical wargames.
JA Back in Action is the 3d re-vision of classical JA2, with new engine based on real-time action with commanding pause mode. To my regret, I wasn’t impressed with that cover-version, so I’m not gonna persuade you to buy it. Game’s decent, even engaging sometimes, but really not that much as original JA2. Even with the all downsides that original Jagged Alliance 2 have, it is still a much better game than its remake Back in Action.

Short audition of features:

1) 3d view works fine enough, but I can’t say same thing about control above the camera view. Due to real-time gaming pattern, I often was in the not-so-fun position where I can see neither enemies, nor my own soldiers in the middle of the shootout. Somebody’s shooting, but who? On whom? It was not obvious way too often. The biggest throw-down of the given 3D engine is not a bad camera, though. It is very limited destructibility. You have plenty of C4 there, but you only allowed blowing certain points at every sector. You can’t even open closed door with the shotgun!

2) All controls are giving the feeling that developers were in need to invent a wheel anew. Or at least, a bicycle. Even moving a map from side to side with the sliding of mouse was added after some patches. And when you‘ll make yourself familiar with the basic controls, you’ll still be wandering with some “decisions” about user interface. Like management of your mercs in teams, or management of inventory of taken sectors.

3) Smart pause mode itself is good, comparing only with the best examples in the genre. But crude AI behavior and sometimes ridiculous camera makes that modus not so desirable, so to say. It is still a good option, but not the essential, like in games on Apeiron engine (7.62, Marauder) or even in the Dragon Age titles.

4) AI of the enemies… they shoot precisely, even with the weakest of weapons, but instead of taking the advantage of those superb skills, they always tend to rush forward, by the shortest path available. And they don’t give much attention to the dead bodies of their comrades, if they don’t heard a shot or seen the shooter. In short, they are quite dumb. There are several maps in the game, where some additional rules were added to enemies behavior, and it is there you’ll probably meet some troubles, and get an urge to plan something ahead. 3-4 serious fights in the whole game, I’d say it’s not enough, but that’s me. Someone likes easy games, and the majority of games now are making for those casual players. So take a hint: buy some PSG-1 rifles and collimators, to shoot far and precise enough, and quite fast at the same time. With those rifles you’ll be having the upper hand almost in every situation that game has for you.

By the way! The AI of guards you’re hiring for defending your sectors… it’s the same as with soldiers, but even worse! They don’t use any tactical advantages of the defending position; they just rush on the bullets! And, unlike the Jagged Alliance 2, you can’t just hire new guards via global map. You need to get some guns, go to the sector where the fight with Deidranna forces was, arm manually each new volunteer… And if he dies, he won’t leave his gun on the body, you need to find or buy a new one. So you need to participate in every fight by yourself, and it will be faster that way.

I can keep up with that list, but that’s major things: the game went in 3D, but became much plainer in the process, if we compare it with the vanilla Jagged Alliance 2. Back In Action took almost everything that wasn’t so necessary and fun, like over-pompious music themes, and constant transitions of items between sectors. A 3D perspective is not bad to have, and smart pause mode can be tolerable. But illogical and un-informative camera views, clumsy controls and blunt behavior of any opponents are not giving the taste of satisfaction even when you prevail above them.

Take me right, I’m not thinking that the Jagged Alliance is a perfect game, even if I’m calling it the king of the tactical genre. Were it up to me, I’d cut or remade some features from it as well, and all that constant fuss with the inventory items, which need to fix, optimize, transfer from sector to sector, from drop zone to battle lines – in the first hand. I’d add some really fitting and atmospheric music to the background, just to fight the urge to fell asleep over the keyboard, while I’m planning another phase of ongoing war conflict. And to think more of it… Maybe the most challenging thing that was made under the brand of Jagged Alliance was not that 2nd game we’re so much talking about? Maybe it is the add-on to the first Jagged Alliance, the Deadly Games? There you have a line of separated missions for your squad of mercs. You have one map, where you fixing all your tasks, and after it, that’s all, you’re victorious! It feels much more refined, than questionable economic system of the JA2 game.

The developers of Back In Action thought in that direction as well. They made two DLC with such maps, in every case you have some quest to get in somewhere and kill there somebody, via some sub-stages on the way. Sadly, but both of those DLC’s are just shown how amateur those developers are. There are different reasons for this conclusion, but hear this: in the mission Shades of Red you need to storm some embassy where hostages are being held. The developers make the several ways to get to that embassy, and the cleverest one was from the basement, which you can penetrate via sewerage tunnel. That way you don’t need to dodge the rockets, which the insurgents will be shooting in case of direct assault. But, but, but… In the end the devs decided it is not good for balance, so now you can’t get to embassy via tunnel. You see it from one end near the river, you can get there with a C4 blast through the wall. But you can’t go further to the tunnel. After you storm the embassy in the hardest, direct assault way, you get down to the basement, and then you see another end of that tunnel, and you realizing, how far Back In Action from the real complete state. Even now, after 3 years after release, with all after-market fixes, like adding the possibility to use mouse to move the map… it is still far from complete, not only in the DLC maps, but in the major game as well.

Finally, so many words after, a conclusion: you CAN buy the Back In Action, if you have a thing for tactical games. It is not a bad game; it is playable and sometimes even brings some fun!

I’ll mark it 6.5/10. It looks good, it sounds and feels almost like old-good Jagged Alliance. Simple-sized for newer, casual players (who can forgot to reload gun between getting into the fights, for example) – but still you controlling a team of mercs, and still you’re in the lead of private war going in the colorful little Latin country. You may find many mods, honing the improvements Back In Action made to Jagged Alliance franchise. There are not so many games in the genre, after all, and Back In Action is certainly not in the worst part of that list.

reviewText: This is not an easy game, so if you are a casual gamer or impatient, pass on this one. Remember that you are a part of a STRUGGLING rebel group trying to overthrow a goverment, so expect it to be difficult to kill hundreds of soldiers with a couple squads of 6 or less mercs(though you can have multiple squads in the same location, you'll just have to tab between them). As a fan of strategy games, I can say that this game does have an unusually steep difficulty curve, but not an impossible one. You can expect to lose and replace squad members(unless you're a fan of copious saving and reloading), and you may have to retreat a few times, but with the right prep work a single mid-level merc can take out a squad of 15 without taking a hit. You MUST have a strategy in mind before moving in, and you must learn to be flexible. As the in-game time progresses, locations receive more and more reinforcements, so you must act quickly to secure a few early and get your daily income up to otherwise the entire game will be an uphill battle. Arming the locals is crucial, unless you leave some mercs behind to defend against the ai squads which is a good idea in a few locations. For those who say this game is too hard, I would be happy to write a strategy guide(not a walkthrough), but only if someone comments that they would like one, not going to spend the time if no-one is going to read it.

reviewText:
I want to like this game. I really want to.

It is a shame that after Jagged Alliance 2 this franchise has been savaged at a pretty good clip.

A continuation of the Jagged Alliance series that doesn't quite fit the bill. At times this game can be HIGHLY and EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING, as the bullet physics simply do not MAKE SENSE. I have had to replay scenario after scenario simply because my sniper who is equipped with a .50 cal barrett and a sniper scope is somehow unable to make a shot within 5 seconds that somehow bounces off an incoming enemy who is running towards my prone merc anticipating a shot.

Jagged Alliance 2 was an amazing game. The characters each had their personalities and idiosyncrasies. This game comes across as feeling flat as there is zero dialogue between mercs.

This game could have been so much more yet the devs failed on a variety of key points.


1.) In this new series, your merc is UNABLE to repair armour. What does this mean? It means that you have to essentially shlep a merc back and forth, running orders for new armour. This translates into a huge waste of time and a waste of money. The game is seriously derailed because after a while you lose your armour and every single enemy AI you encounter has brand new armour. Lame.

2.) The game is highly unbalanced and the devs are incompetent about this. It requires Ivan 6 seconds using a Barrett .50 cal with a scope to take a shot and all of his attributes are 90+ across the board. Yet it takes an enemy AI 2 seconds standing up to squeeze round after round and Ivan is dead before he gets a shot off. Idiotic.

3.) It took me a record FIVE SHOTS from a PSG-1 50 feet away to drop an enemy AI. Each shot the enemy just shook it off. One shot alone with a 7.62 round 50 feet away to your head and your head would magically disappear into a fine mist. And yet the dev at BitComposer overlook this glaring fact.

4.) Waiting patiently works against you. By the time I was ready and good to attack major cities, the number of enemy AI had bloated to over 80 a city. It took me around 3 hours of repeated saving and trying before I was able to take over the Docks which had 40 dead enemies. Ridiculous.

5.) Enemy AI shooting mechanics are UNREALISTIC. I have had a merc prone some 50 feet away on an incline, which means he is facing the slope before having reached it. The other side the enemy AI has somehow managed to SHOOT ME THROUGH THE ♥♥♥♥ING HILL. Seriously...

6.) Enemy AI will spot you miles down the road. Camouflage does not work. I have had snipers prone among trees and grass blended right in and the AI has been able to see me and also SHOOT ME THROUGH TREES AND ROCKS.

7.) Camouflage counts for nothing.

8.) The game forces you to heavily rely on micromanagement of cities with its system of hiring miltia. In Jagged Alliance 2 you could simply equip militia and watch a quick run through as they fount incoming troops. Whatever leftover troops were automatically leveled up. After a while, you could have a full compliment of militia and ANY town would be safe. In Back in Action, the computer will forever send 10 man teams to Cambria. Seeing that Cambria is an important city with its arms dealer, you are forced to park mercs to defend it.

9.) Regular militia are essentially useless. There are no defensive capabilities with militia. You can equip them with the latest weapons and armour and they will simply walk out in the open and get mowed down. It will cost you 10s of thousands to continue equipping them with weapons.

10.) There are no interrupts in this game like there were in Jagged Alliance 2 which is a shame, since you were rewarded for carefully planning your moves.

11.) Even with the balancing mod, your mercs take far too long to shoot. While it makes sense to take longer to peer down a scope and shoot, trained mercs in real-life who use red-dot sites or holographic sights can shoot in under 2 seconds at a target. In this game you can be lying prone on the ground with a machine gun and it will take your merc 2-3 seconds to ready himself to shoot while the AI will mow you down.

Unless you are willing to play a game that involves loading save after save hours on end, don't bother getting this. If you do get this, get the Realism Balanced mod which not only addresses the glaring gun flaws but adds new weapons. It makes the game playable.

All I want to ask the devs is, WTF kind of QA do you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ do at BitComposer?

Take a look at the screenshot below.  Wolf is UNDER WATER hidden behind trees with roots blocking the view. And yet he is still spotted. W T F IS THIS B U L L S H I T

http://i.imgur.com/WrxqmVn.jpg

Do not buy this game unless you want to spend 90% of your time reloading save after save.

What's german for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ devs who make broken games?

reviewText:
Back In Action is one of those titles were the Metascore actually says it all. 62 % average is actually rather generous.

Jagged Alliance 2 still remains my favorite game of all times and is right up there with X-COM as prime examples of TBS gaming at it's best. Back in Action is the tragic reality of what happens when classic IP's go up for sale in a gaming industry were Call of Duty and Halo are the kind of titles that investors would rather commit to.

Back in Action does not deserve to carry the name. And BitComposer has done the franchise a great injustice by allowing such a game to be made, and not to mention alienating the old fans by asking us for our input (via their forum in the infancy of the games development) and then doing the exact opposite of what the majority asked for.

And when sales and reviews were terrible... they still insisted that Turn Based Games are dead... And then XCOM Enemy Unknown was released...

If you never played JA or you aren't to concerned with deep strategic gameplay mixed with a serious learning curb, then you might enjoy this. If you like a good TBS title, XCOM Enemy Unknown isn't without its faults, but is leagues above this poorly designed attempt at cashing in on a cult classic. Especially with the DLC's included (like Enemy Within).

reviewText:
In my mind, there are Four aspects that make up a game. There's the Story (within that, the character development), The Gameplay (within that, the difficulty), The Graphics (within this, the audio as well as the visual.) and the game's ability to be enjoyed (and replayability, of course.). Naturally, there's also bugs as an issue but, that's something that works out over time.

JA:BIA is a Mediocre game. It has passable graphics and audio (for a relatively minor B grade game), next to no story (they didn't need to develop the story - the story existed from the origins of this game) and acceptable gameplay. The Gameplay is RTwP (real time with pause) which is a fantastic genre that people don't see enough of, or appreciate at all. While it's not the TBS of the original games, this particular form of gameplay is very entertaining, bringing one to the last note on this list, the game's ability to be enjoyed.

If you have played the original JA games, you probably won't like this as a JA game. IF you pretend it's not a JA game, it's pretty fun. So, my word to you is to play it as if it were not a JA game, but simply a game to stand on its own two feet. It deserves some attention for its gameplay delivery. I'd give it a solid 6/10. It's not fantastic, but you'll definitely get your money's worth.

If you can get past that, Jagged Alliance - Back in Action is quite possibly the best recent western-style squad based tactical RPG out at time of writing. The terrain is beautiful, and tactically significant. The weapons are varied and each can shine paired an appropriate combat style. The combat system is the smoothest and most satisfying attempt to meld real-time action and turn-based planning that I've ever played. Now that it's been patched, you can even adjust the tactical elements and difficulty to match the level of challenge you want. And if you're interested but not sold, Coreplay is among the disturbingly small club of developers that bothered to make a demo to introduce you to their product. Try it and see what you think... just don't charge toward the red marks as soon as the map loads. That's for bulls.

reviewText:
Despite its flaws, I loved this game. I played it to completion and enjoyed it immensely. It may not do tactical combat as well as the original Jagged Alliance series, but for me the visceral feel of the pausable-real-time gameplay makes up for it. I bought the bundle for $13.59 a while back and I was thoroughly satisfied with my purchase; it's currently on sale for even less than that.

Probably the most satisfying moments were the close quarters blasts, whether charging into a room with a shotgun or waiting for an enemy just around the corner with a readied assault rifle or machinegun. The AI is too predictable for a conservative strategy to be very enjoyable in most cases. It was often possible, but not very rewarding, to grind the enemy down from long range, with the exception of a few spots in the game where a daring assault is necessary due to the layout. But sending Wolf running into a room to empty his shotgun into an enemy's guts never got old for me.

The chief feature of combat in this game, and to my knowledge what sets it apart from all other games, is the timer that begins counting when you order your merc to fire a shot. The time to take a shot is a simple mechanic, but it has critical consequences for how you plan your tactics. Timing interacts with posture, so that postures where you take less accurate shots also allow you to get your shots off faster. It also depends on your choice of firearm, as well as the range. In a close quarters encounter, who gets off the first shot is the difference between life and death. You need to understand and take advantage of this mechanic to play the game effectively. In my opinion, more than anything else this one thing is what makes the game interesting.

I liked the artwork, especially in the cities. I've been to Latin America a number of times, and the look of the buildings gave the place an authentic Caribbean feel. The look of the game gives you the feeling that you're fighting over real places in the real world. The characters' accents are silly (as is the minimal plot), but that's in keeping with the original Jagged Alliance games and it's entertaining if you're not touchy about such things.

I wasn't too crazy about the defensive part of this game. The militia is useless, so you have to park a squad in one place to stop enemy attacks. (Since enemy squads always follow nearly the same path, they always come up the road into the same city, and always from exactly the same angle.) While I got some entertainment out of devising different ways to defend the chokepoint, it wasn't much of a serious challenge one I realized that I could clog the enemy's entry path with mines and take out half of the assault party before they got close enough to shoot at me. Since I kept defending the same terrain over and over, it would have been nice to be able to erect some kind of fortifications.

I change to recommended because I have spend 100+ hours on this game and I enjoy this game as long as I set my mind this game is just some sort of real time tactical squad game with pause (RTwP) with no personality. It might taste bland but this is offset by some cool graphics and nice level design. I was expecting some underground level but hey this is good enough to be enjoyed.

Old Review (Not Recommended)
-------------------------------------------------

If I have to describe this game in a single sentence I'll have to say this game doesn't capture the essence of what makes Jagged Alliance a great game - interesting characterization and challenging combat. Though technically this Back In Action (BIA) games is superior in term of graphic and some of level design are good, it fails royally in other aspect which makes JA1 and JA2 a great game.

OK lets see what the developer of this game failed:

1) Cumbersome combat system. I don't mind playing this game as real time combat game but the implementation of this system in the game is so mediocre it ruins the game. The camera keep changing during pause while really annoys me. I think I spend a lot of time fixing the camera view than actually playing the game which kind of shame.

2) Weak characterization in term of dialog, voice over and portrait. I'm quite baffled why the developer can't just reuse the old voice over which is great. That's one of the biggest selling feature of old Jagged Alliance games. The new dialog and voice over is horrible by Jagged Alliance standard. Lets not even talk about that 3D portrait (only Spider looks good). It looks odd and playing with cumbersome combat and sub-standard voice over, you wonder is this really Jagged Alliance that used to be a great game?

Simply put, this is not a Jagged Alliance games. Only in name but not in the spirit of what makes Jagged Alliance a great game. I'm trying to finish this game but I can't promise that.

reviewText:
I've played almost 100h with this product, So you can definitely see that I liked it.

I played JG2 in the past. It was very hard game, with strong team management and fruitfull (and very frustratic) battles over all places in Arulco. Sinde then, any many many mods we all waits for an other step into the genre.

Instead of next step we have simply remake. It has very nice graphic, and new deep of battles density thanks to plan'n'action game style. Please, take a note: this is not RTS game, your boys and girls dies bloody fast (and aims terribly bad). You need to use covers, silence killing, melee skills, land mines and everything you can got from you squads (automated rocket rifle rocks!). On this part I haven't found many bugs (most likely game is well patched now), only one frustratic bug:
When your mercs are in small space, AI have very big issues to avoid collissions. I don'd need to explain that such situation during firefight usually ends with save loading or with farewell to your wonderfull killers.

Of course in compare to the previous JA game (especially JA2), this product have some not implemented features, and that  makes game too easy on management level (especially if you don't want to speed up too much like me):
- Merc contract NEVER ends - so if you play a long game, it's quite easy to have almost all mercs (obviously some of them don't want to work with each other)
- Mines resources (so also your income) never ends.

I hope, I don't need to explain that without such limitations, you end up with stack of useless money (I've ended with 900k), for which you're buing repair kits, special ammo or Guardian vests at best. Most of the weapon or ammo, or even bunch of granades are easy to gather from army of dead enemies.

Also If you gather good team with 2 paramedics and 1 Sniper (I've used my Amazon team for this with Raven, Spider, Fox, Vicki and 2 others) then you can simply go through the whole map, in the gaps between enemy zones and simply take over southern Sam site (next to Meduna). After that you can be sure that any Queen attacking party will be stopped there, and it's very easy to defend in entrance, especially with mine field.

So in general: I liked game VERY much, I enjoyed the time I spent on it and for sure I'll back to it with some mods that are available over internet, but for some veterans it might be a little bit too easy, especially when you setup your ground.

It released with some issues, but steady support has improved the game to the point that it is now a decent game. The 3D implementation is decent although at times I miss the superior detail and character of Jagged Alliance 2's 2D graphics, and the mercs don't quite have the same personality as they did before.

In the end, despite the more modern technical advances, JABiA is still not as endearing a game as JA2. However, what is there is a playable product with a pretty solid tactical model that still has some flaws (the speed model, which determines who shoots first in an engagement, doesn't always yield results that make sense. And the implementation of explosive destruction of the environment is very limited.

Still, improvements such as the addition of sector inventory and numerous bug fixes show the developer commitment. There is plenty to do in the base game; lots of quests and goals. DLC adds a bit more. The price has come down now and it's a better deal than it used to be. Even though it is flawed I found myself playing quite a bit.
